resource.chars:
columnar cells inosculate with each other:- 100 diam.
4. Tangential section of a fossil disk of complex type, showing
four columnar cells <u>aa'</u>, <u>bb'</u>, <u>cc'</u>, <u>dd'</u>, of the same zone,
divided by sinuous partitions, with the orifices leading
into the columnar cells of the next interior zone:- 100 diam.
5. Similar tangential section, showing <s>the</s> four cells of the
next-interior zone, <u>aa'</u>, <u>bb'</u>, <u>cc'</u>, <u>dd'</u>, alternating with the preceding, and
the <s>a</s> entrance of the passages of the same vertical row,
alternately into one and the other of the cells on the
two sides of each of the sinuous vertical partitions:- 100 diam.
6. Radial section of a fossil disk, showing the incom-
pleteness of the separation of the <s>su</s> superficial cells
from the <s>col</s> intermediate layer, and the irregularity
of the <s>structure</s> arrangement of its cells, with their numerous lateral
inosculations (compare Pl. VII, Figs 2,3):- 48 diam.
7. Radial section of a thicker fossil disk, showing a
more regular arrangement of the columnar cells of the
intermediate layer (still, however, with numerous pas-
sages for lateral inosculation), and the complete continui-
ty of the superficial cells with these:- 48 diam.
